text: I was invited to participate in a prototype version of an AR/VR workshop run by Oregon Story Board. They are a non-profit dedicated to advancing digital storytelling and they’ve recently been highly focused on AR/VR. They’re toying around with running workshops to introduce people to the different technologies/platforms and how to build/design for them. They’ve done a bunch of workshops with developers but are really interested in working with designers and understanding how these tools might fit into a design process. I am going to see if we can arrange another workshop (we’d have to pay for it, not sure how much yet) because I think that a lot of folks would find it really fun/interesting. I played around with a number of different applications but this one (or something like it) seem incredibly useful for prototyping/sketching in 3d. Was thinking about BrandLab a lot.
Very interesting, thanks for sharing Melissa. The application looks pretty artistic, so it'll depend on application. Would love to try myself.
yeah this particular app is meant to be more art focused. More of an MS Paint than an Adobe Illustrator, speaking in 2D terms. It will be really interesting to see where this tech goes.
but it was a pretty incredible experience being able to draw AROUND you and move in and out of a sketch and see it at a human scale.

another technology i got to play with is Microsoft’s HoloLens, a mixed-reality headset that has a lot of interesting potential for collaborative learning, museums, libraries, as well as gaming/looking like an asshole in public <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SKpKlh1-en0>

text: all of this stuff is basically still in demo-land, but it’s really interesting to think about the potential
plus fun to fool around with
